subj-group.subject: Reconstructive: Head and Neck: Original Articles

title-group.article-title: A Novel Risk Model for Predicting Dysphagia after Tongue Reconstruction: A Retrospective Multicenter Study in Japan

contrib-group.on-behalf-of: On behalf of the OPERA Study Group

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: There is no consensus on the postoperative outcomes of tongue reconstruction. Therefore, the authors developed a novel risk model for predicting dysphagia after tongue reconstruction.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: This retrospective study was conducted by the Oral Pharyngeal Esophageal Operation and Reconstruction Analytical, or OPERA, group across 31 cancer centers and university hospitals in Japan. A total of 532 patients [390 (73.3%) men and 142 (26.7%) women; median age at surgery, 60 years (range, 15 to 88 years)] who were diagnosed with oral tongue squamous cell carcinoma and underwent tongue reconstruction following glossectomy between 2009 and 2013 were included. Independent risk factors were identified using univariate regression analysis and converted to a binary format for multivariate analysis. An integer value was assigned to each risk factor to calculate a total score capable of quantifying the risk of feeding tube dependence.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Overall, 54 patients (10.2%) required a feeding tube at the time of evaluation. Predictive factors for feeding tube dependence were advanced age, lower American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status, low body mass index, lower serum albumin, comorbid hypertension and diabetes, extended tongue defect, resection beyond the tongue, laryngeal suspension, postoperative radiation therapy, and no functional teeth. In multivariate logistic regression analysis, age greater than or equal to 58.5 years, postoperative radiation therapy, wider tongue defect, and body mass index less than 21.27 kg/m2 earned 6, 4, 3, and 2 points, respectively, for a maximum total score of 15.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The authors’ risk model provides a mathematical tool for estimating the individual risk of postoperative feeding tube dependence before tongue reconstruction.

sec.title: CLINICAL QUESTION/LEVEL OF EVIDENCE:
sec.p: Risk, III.

body.p: Oral tongue squamous cell carcinoma (OTSCC) is an orphan malignant disease (ORPHA: 457252, www.orpha.net), and its incidence is increasing globally.1 OTSCC is a head and neck tumor characterized by a firm infiltrative neoplasm with squamous differentiation arising from the mucosal epithelium; it is most commonly located in the tongue, floor of the mouth, or gingiva, and may also occur in the buccal mucosa or any other area of the oral cavity. Tumor location depends on the prevailing risk factors, including smoking, alcohol consumption, and chronic mechanical irritation. Patients have various white, erythematous, mixed, nodular, or ulcerated lesions, which may cause discomfort, pain, or reduced tongue mobility. The tumor is aggressive, with a propensity for local invasion and early lymph node metastasis.

OTSCC is staged based on tumor, node, and metastasis (TNM) staging rules, and resectable tumors are treated surgically.2 Chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy are considered for patients with unresectable tumors or at high risk of recurrence. The appropriate surgical procedure is selected for resectable tumors based on patient age, general health status, and occupation. Some patients experience permanent disabilities including dysphagia and/or dysarthria because of glossectomy. Resection of more than half of the whole tongue (hemiglossectomy, subtotal or total glossectomy) requires immediate reconstructive surgery with a pedicled or free flap. Reconstructive procedures are diverse and often differ based on surgeon preferences and among institutions. There is no consensus on postoperative outcomes, although several small single-center studies have been published on this topic.3–12

This is the first synthetic retrospective multicenter study on functional outcomes after tongue reconstruction; in addition, we report the development of a risk model of dysphagia (feeding tube dependence) statistically powered by multivariate logistic regression analyses of 532 cases from 31 institutions.

sec.title: Setting and Study Design
sec.p: A retrospective multicenter study was conducted by the Oral Pharyngeal Esophageal Operation and Reconstruction Analytical (OPERA) study group across 31 cancer centers and university hospitals in Japan. The participating institutions and investigators are listed. (See Table, Supplemental Digital Content 1, which lists the participating institutions and investigators, http://links.lww.com/PRS/G142.) All patients who were diagnosed with OTSCC and underwent tongue reconstruction following glossectomy between 2009 and 2013 were included. The inclusion criteria were local diagnosis of OTSCC at the initial histopathologic examination of the primary tumor and tongue reconstruction by pedicled or free flap transfer. Exclusion criteria included distant metastases, double cancer, and recurrence during the observation period. Functional evaluation was performed between 6 months and 1 year after surgery. The primary endpoint was postoperative feeding tube dependence. The study protocol was approved by the ethics committee of the Shizuoka Cancer Center Hospital (approval number T26-29-26) and was subsequently approved by all participating institutions. Procedures, including obtaining informed consent, were conducted in accordance with the ethical standards of the committee on human experimentation of the participating institutions.

sec.title: Data Acquisition
sec.p: Clinical data (patient background, intraoperative and postoperative findings, and functional outcome between 6 months and 1 year after surgery) of candidates were retrieved using a uniform case report form from the individual institutions. In case of inconsistencies, the original patient health records were reviewed, and missing data were included. In particular, data on patient background included age, sex, American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status classification, body mass index (BMI), blood albumin level, blood hemoglobin level, tobacco use, alcohol consumption, medical comorbidities (hypertension, diabetes, cardiac dysrhythmia, peripheral vascular diseases, cranial neuropathy, neuromuscular disorders, and psychiatric disorders), and preoperative therapies (radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and surgery). Data on perioperative findings included TNM classification, tongue defects (types 1 to 8), resection beyond the tongue, neck dissection, reconstructive procedures (procedures for anterolateral thigh, rectus abdominis, forearm, pectoralis major, groin, latissimus dorsi, fibula, scapula, and others), operation time, blood loss, tracheotomy, laryngeal suspension, cricopharyngeal myotomy, postoperative complications, additional surgery, postoperative radiation therapy, rehabilitation, oral care, shape of the tongue (protuberant, flat, or depressed), and functional teeth. Functional outcome was evaluated by presence of postoperative feeding tube dependence between 6 months and 1 year after surgery, which was the primary endpoint. The extent of glossectomy was classified into eight types as follows (Fig. 1): type 1, oral hemiglossectomy (hemiresection of the oral tongue); type 2, oral hemiglossectomy with partial resection of the tongue base; type 3, hemiglossectomy (hemiresection of the whole tongue); type 4, total oral glossectomy (total resection of the oral tongue); type 5, subtotal oral glossectomy with partial resection of the base of the tongue; type 6, subtotal oral glossectomy with hemiresection of tongue base; type 7, subtotal glossectomy (subtotal resection of the whole tongue); and type 8, total glossectomy (total resection of the whole tongue). These categorical variables were reduced to binary variables for multivariate logistic regression analysis as follows: less than subtotal glossectomy or total oral glossectomy (types 1 to 4) and subtotal or total glossectomy (types 5 to 8).

caption.p: Extent of glossectomy. Type 1, oral hemiglossectomy (hemiresection of the oral tongue); type 2, oral hemiglossectomy with partial resection of the base of the tongue; type 3, hemiglossectomy (hemiresection of the whole tongue); type 4, total oral glossectomy (total resection of the oral tongue); type 5, subtotal oral glossectomy with partial resection of the tongue base; type 6, subtotal oral glossectomy with hemiresection of the base of the tongue; type 7, subtotal glossectomy (subtotal resection of the whole tongue); and type 8, total glossectomy (total resection of the whole tongue).

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Statistical analyses were performed using R version 4.0.5 (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria). Median, maximum, and minimum values were calculated for continuous quantity data to perform simple and lesser tests. The frequency in each category was calculated for categorical data. The likelihood ratio test was performed, and univariate logistic regression models were constructed to identify predictors of postoperative feeding tube dependence. Continuous variables were converted into categorical variables to construct a risk score. Dichotomization was based on clinical significance and optimal cutoffs from receiver operating characteristic analysis. Each predictor in the final model was weighted based on the estimated coefficient. Risk score was calculated using the weight of each predictor for each patient. Because this was an exploratory study, multiple testing corrections were not performed. Values of P < 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Clinical Characteristics
sec.p: In total, 532 patients who underwent tongue reconstruction were included. The median age at surgery was 60 years (range, 15 to 88 years), and the population included 390 (73.3%) male and 142 (26.7%) female patients. The clinical characteristics of the patients, including medical history, are shown in Table 1.

ASA physical status, a commonly used perioperative assessment parameter,13 was used to evaluate patients’ general condition. Overall, 245 (46.1%), 180 (33.8%), and 25 (4.7%) patients were evaluated as classes 1, 2, and 3, respectively, and 82 (15.4%) patients were of an unknown class. The median BMI was 21.9 kg/m2 (range, 13.8 to 35.9 kg/m2); the median serum albumin and hemoglobin levels were 4.2 g/dL (range, 2.2 to 5.2 g/dL) and 13.3 g/dL (range, 7.9 to 44.1 g/dL), respectively. A total of 333 (62.6%) patients had a smoking history [median Brinkman index, 600 (range, 3 to 5000)]; 166 patients (31.2%) did not have a smoking history. A total of 356 patients (66.9%) had a history of alcohol consumption, and 166 (31.2%) did not. In the study population, 157 (29.5%), 86 (16.2%), 33 (6.2%), six (1.1%), 19 (3.6%), 10 (1.9%), and 30 (5.6%) patients had hypertension, diabetes, cardiac dysrhythmia, peripheral vascular disease, cerebral disease, neuromuscular disorders, and psychiatric disorders, respectively. Regarding preoperative therapies, 58 (11.0%), 181 (34.0%), and 93 (17.5%) patients had undergone radiation [median dose, 50 Gy (range, 20 to 90 Gy)], chemotherapy, and surgery, respectively.

Perioperative details are shown in Table 2. Tumor staging was performed according to the TNM Atlas (7th edition; International Union Against Cancer).14,15 The most commonly observed type of tongue defect was type 2 [124 patients (24.2%)], followed by type 1 [99 patients (18.6%)] and type 5 [87 patients (16.4%)]. Resection beyond the extent of the tongue (such as segmental mandibulectomy and/or tonsillectomy) was performed in a small group of patients [156 patients (29.3%)], whereas most patients [374 patients (70.3%)] did not undergo such resections. Neck dissection was performed in 525 patients (98.7%). The most prevalent tongue reconstruction procedure was that using an anterolateral thigh flap [219 patients (41.1%)], followed by reconstruction with a rectus abdominis flap [190 patients (35.7%)] and forearm flap [94 patients (17.7%)]. The median operation time and blood loss were 600 minutes (range, 238 to 1353 minutes) and 382.5 mL (range, 20 to 2195 mL), respectively. Although most patients [508 patients (95.5%)] underwent tracheotomy, only a few patients [121 patients (22.7%)] underwent laryngeal suspension and cricopharyngeal myotomy [30 patients (5.6%)]. Postoperative complications were observed in 147 (27.6%) patients, and 69 (13.0%) patients required additional surgery for complications. Postoperative radiation therapy was performed in 167 patients (31.4%). A total of 205 patients underwent dysphagia rehabilitation. Oral care was performed in 400 patients (75.2%) and was not administered in 131 patients (24.6%). At the time of evaluation, the tongue shape was protuberant in 271 patients (50.9%), flat in 128 patients (24.1%), depressed in 16 patients (3.0%), and unknown in 117 patients (22.0%). Opposing teeth and/or prosthetic dental implants (functional teeth) were observed in 406 patients (76.3%), whereas they were not present in 77 patients (14.5%).

sec.title: Predictive Factors and Risk Scores of Feeding Tube Dependence
sec.p: Overall, 54 (10.2%) patients depended on tube feeding, 35 (6.6%) were partially dependent, and 19 (3.6%) were totally dependent at the time of evaluation. Prognostic factors associated with postoperative feeding tube dependence per univariate analysis are shown in Table 3: advanced age (P < 0.0001), lower ASA physical status (P = 0.00182 and P = 0.03510), lower BMI (P = 0.00958), lower serum albumin (P = 0.00928), comorbid hypertension (P = 0.00516), diabetes (P = 0.0429), cerebral disease (P = 0.0246), extended tongue defect, resection beyond the tongue (P = 0.00492), laryngeal suspension (P = 0.0051), postoperative radiation therapy (P = 3.15e-05), and no functional teeth (P = 0.000409). Clinically important factors with smaller P values were included in the list of prognostic factors associated with postoperative feeding tube dependence in multivariate analysis.

caption.p: Prognostic Factors Associated with Postoperative Feeding Tube Dependence in Univariate Analysis

fn.p: ALT, anterolateral thigh; RA, rectus abdominis; PM, pectoralis major; LD, latissimus dorsi; W/U, without unknown.

sec.p: After converting the type of tongue defect parameter to a binary format for multivariate analysis, significant prognostic parameters were retained as follows: advanced age (OR, 1.084; 95% CI, 1.053 to 1.120; P = 3.45e-07), low BMI (OR, 1.112; 95% CI, 1.011 to 1.230; P = 0.03294), extended tongue defect (type 1 to 4 versus type 5 to 8) (OR, 2.859; 95% CI, 1.531 to 5.443; P = 0.00111), and postoperative irradiation (OR, 4.112; 95% CI, 2.194 to 7.868; P = 1.31e-05). (See Table, Supplemental Digital Content 2, which lists prognostic factors associated with postoperative feeding tube dependence in multivariate analysis, http://links.lww.com/PRS/G143.)

We analyzed the correlation between the three most common flaps used for reconstruction and factors such as age at surgery, BMI, tongue defect type, postoperative radiation therapy, and tongue shape to identify selection bias. Anterolateral thigh flaps were used in younger patients. Rectus abdominis flaps were used in patients with lower BMIs and larger tongue defects. Forearm flaps were used in patients with smaller tongue defects. Interestingly, the tongue shape showed no correlation with these three flaps (Table 4).

caption.p: Correlation between Three Most Common Flaps and Other Prognostic Factors

fn.p: ALT, anterolateral thigh; RA, rectus abdominis.

sec.p: Using the coefficients of each independent predictor from the multivariable logistic regression model, we assigned an integer value for each risk factor to calculate a total score capable of quantifying the risk of feeding tube dependence. The cutoff values were set at age 58.5 years and BMI of 21.27 kg/m2. ORs for postoperative feeding tube dependence were 6.449 (95% CI, 2.96 to 16.235) for age, 1.792 (95% CI, 0.968 to 3.36) for BMI, 2.692 (95% CI, 1.461 to 5.046) for tongue defects, and 3.639 (95% CI, 1.973 to 6.812) for postoperative irradiation. ORs were rounded off, and risk scores were calculated. Overall, age greater than or equal to 58.5 years, postoperative radiation therapy, tongue defect types 5 to 8, and BMI less than 21.27 kg/m2 earned 6, 4, 3, and 2 points, respectively, for a maximum total score of 15 (Table 5).

caption.p: Risk Scoring System for Postoperative Feeding Tube Dependence after Tongue Reconstruction

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This retrospective multicenter study is the largest study on tongue reconstruction and includes 532 patients from 31 institutions in Japan; this study also adds significant findings to the existing literature. Oncologically, resectable OTSCC has a relatively good prognosis; therefore, an important issue related to treatment and outcomes is reconstruction and rehabilitation.15 As cancers of the oral cavity and oropharynx can directly impact the function of the teeth, tongue, mandible, palate, and pharynx, patients with OTSCC often present with disruption of their abilities to eat, drink, chew, and swallow.16

sec.title: Prognostic Factors of Postoperative Feeding Tube Dependence in Univariate and Multivariate Analyses
sec.p: Advanced age increased the risk of feeding tube dependence after tongue reconstruction, in line with previous reports,5,6 and was reported as a limiting factor for laryngeal preservation after head and neck reconstruction.17,18 Older patients have less reserve capacity for swallowing than younger patients. Specifically, reduced maximal lingual pressure, incomplete relaxation of the upper esophageal sphincter, and delayed triggering of the swallowing reflex are reportedly the primary causes of functional loss because of aging.19,20 In elderly patients, recurrent aspiration pneumonia often becomes life threatening and significantly diminishes the patient’s quality of life. Preoperative evaluation of reserve capacity is important when screening candidates for significant glossectomy with laryngeal preservation.21

Our results showed that postoperative radiation therapy also increased the risk of dysphagia, as described previously.3,5,6,8 Radiation therapy to the head and neck causes mucositis, ulceration, and pseudomembrane formation, which are associated with oral pain and odynophagia, resulting in altered oral intake.16 In addition, atrophy of the transferred flap because of radiation therapy is inevitable and can adversely affect swallowing function.22 While planning the treatment for high-risk patients, physicians should weigh the survival benefits against the functional sequelae of the combined-modality treatment. The present results will allow physicians to set functional expectations more appropriately after tongue reconstruction and adjuvant radiation therapy.

Several authors have reported that the extent of tongue resection was the most important determinant of functional outcome after tongue reconstruction.23–25 Our data also showed that worsening of swallowing function was directly related to the extent of tongue defect. However, type 4 defects (total oral glossectomy without involving the base of the tongue) have a relatively favorable outcome (95.5% of patients were not dependent on the feeding tube), which corroborates the importance of the high swallowing pressures produced at the tongue base.26,27

Low BMI and low serum albumin levels are associated with a significantly increased risk of postoperative feeding tube dependence.3,6 This fact suggests high prevalence of malnutrition and sarcopenia, which negatively affect quality of life in dysphagia patients.28,29 Poor general health conditions indicated by ASA physical status, comorbid hypertension, and diabetes are also associated with postoperative feeding tube dependence. Comorbid cerebral disease also increased the risk of postoperative feeding tube dependence, probably because of dysphagia related to brain dysfunction.30 However, anemia indicated by low hemoglobin levels, comorbid cardiac dysrhythmia, and peripheral vascular diseases were not risk factors for postoperative feeding tube dependence.

Resection beyond the tongue, into the palate, tonsilla, and/or mandible is related to swallowing dysfunction, as described previously.3–6 In cases of extensive or complex head and neck defects, multiple simultaneous microvascular free flap reconstructions may be necessary to maximize quality of life in patients with advanced disease.31 Patients who underwent laryngeal suspension and/or cricopharyngeal myotomy showed a trend of postoperative feeding tube dependence, although these procedures were applied to improve swallowing function. This is explained by the fact that cricopharyngeal myotomy, laryngeal suspension, or both are often performed in patients considered at high risk of dysphagia, such as those with excision of the bilateral suprahyoid muscles.32 Surgeons identified these patients as being at high risk of dysphasia and performed the procedures to reduce the risk; however, this obviously did not fully accomplish the goals. Edentulous patients had a high risk of swallowing dysfunction, consistent with previous findings.33 Such patients use the tongue instead of the teeth to stabilize the mandible, which is an important part of swallowing. Dental therapies including prosthetic implants and dentures are considered to have clinical benefits.

There is obvious selection bias regarding the flap suitable for specific tongue defects. Each flap has considerably different characteristics, muscle composition, and, most importantly, volume. Herein, flap selection was appropriately performed without affecting the tongue shape. Therefore, reconstructive procedure was not a prognostic factor for postoperative feeding tube dependence. However, design innovations or innervation improvements may contribute to better outcomes in individual patients.17,34,35

sec.title: Risk Model of Postoperative Feeding Tube Dependence
sec.p: The cumulative distribution of each risk score is illustrated in the staircase graph in Figure 2 (above, left). None of the patients had a risk score of 1 or 14. As the patients with a risk score of less than 6 points did not depend on postoperative tube feeding, they were classified as having no risk in this analysis (class 0). The other risk scores were divided by 3; scores of 6 to 8 were classified as low risk (class 1), scores of 9 to 11 were classified as moderate risk (class 2), and scores of 12 to 15 were classified as high risk (class 3). A majority of patients with postoperative feeding tube dependence (35%) were categorized in the high-risk class (class 3), whereas 19% were categorized as class 2 and 11% as class 1 (Fig. 2, above, right). A receiver operating characteristic curve of this risk model was constructed, and the Youden index showed sensitivity of 86.8% and specificity of 53.6% (Fig. 2, below).

caption.p: Risk model of postoperative feeding tube dependence. The cumulative distribution of each risk score is illustrated in the staircase graph (above, left). The percentage of postoperative feeding tube dependence was 0% in class 0 (score, 0 to 5), 11% in class 1 (score, 6 to 8), 19% in class 2 (score, 9 to 11), and 35% in class 3 (score, 12 to 15) (above, right). The Youden index showed a sensitivity of 86.8% and specificity of 53.6% in the receiver operating characteristic curve of the risk model (below). We used the statistically optimal cutoff value based on the receiver operating characteristic curve, and we believe that this risk model effectively models the clinical observations. However, it should be noted that the risk score presented here is the result of exploratory analysis and has not been internally or externally validated. Here, we have only proposed this risk model, and validation will be performed in the currently ongoing prospective study being conducted by the Oral Pharyngeal Esophageal Operation and Reconstruction Analytical (OPERA) group and in follow-up studies by other groups.

sec.p: The study strength is the large sample size of 532 pooled patients from 31 institutions. In addition, potential bias was reduced because each institution reported three or more cases to the registry. Another important advantage is that the risk modeling of feeding tube dependence was statistically corroborated by multivariate logistic regression analyses. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on risk modeling for tongue reconstruction.

This study has several limitations. The main limitation is that the study was registry-based, and many of the included data sets were incomplete. Because of the small number of events, sufficient variables could not be included in multivariate analysis. The large number of futile events was of central importance for the study because it increased the statistical power of the analysis.36 We plan to conduct a prospective study of tongue reconstruction to resolve these issues. In addition, we plan to develop a risk model for other outcomes, such as patient satisfaction and speech.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Our risk model provides a mathematical tool that can be used to estimate the individual risk of postoperative feeding tube dependence before tongue reconstruction. This method may substantiate clinicians’ best judgment and complementarily assist proper patient selection and surgical decision-making for reconstructive surgery in OTSCC.

sec.title: DISCLOSURE
sec.p: The authors report no commercial associations or financial disclosures regarding this article.

sec.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

Fuji Foundation for Healthcare Innovation and Cluster Development–Pharma Valley Center for data management and study management. The authors also thank Hiromi Hifumi for technical assistance and Samsudeen Saidu from Editage for English-language editing.
